column6: Our findings provide the missing evidence-base for the new national strategy to expand immigrant screening
column12: The UK should radically change its tuberculosis screening policy and include arrivals from the Indian subcontinent, which could prevent most cases of the disease, according to scientists in a paper published today.
column14: mean that people with imported latent TB could be given a course of antibiotics to prevent them from developing an active form of the disease.
column33: Professor Ajit Lalvani, of Imperial College London, argues that new blood tests should be used to pick-up cases where people are carrying TB infection but will not develop it for several years.
column36: Untreated TB leads to many unnecessary deaths and a great deal of suffering, and if this new approach to screening is adopted we may at last move towards reducing TB in this country
column37: "By changing the threshold for screening, and including immigrants from the Indian subcontinent, we could pick up 92 percent of imported latent TB,"
